RADIO PROGRAMMING IN THE FACE OF TV
Dick Vogl, Program Director, WOI
(The following is an abbreviated version of his talk,)
Basic program-production staffs at WOI are separate. We feel this is the best way
to overcome the TV GIANT and preserve our 31-year investment in radio. Radio
staff inaugurated a campaign to STAMP OUT TV. This was unsuccessful. TV at the
outset, at least, has too much glamour for that. People watch it as long as some¬
thing wiggles. It has the attraction of a child’s new toy. Newspapers give it
all kinds of free publicity.. .the fact that the ’’story’1 is about TV makes it ’’news.”
Radio programming within this framework becomes critical. We make it a point (with¬
in practical limitations) to offer alternate programs... the old idea which many
educational radio stations have used successfully against commercial radio. We
try to program a strong ’’culture” show on radio across from a weak "entertainment”
feature on TV.
We let the TV audience know what’s offered on radio. Whenever possible we insert
a radio promotion spot, calling attention to a specific radio show, on TV ahead of
the low-grade television program. For instance: "Tonight ’Ways of Mankind’ tells
the story of THE BORROWED WIFE over WOI-FM. This program can be heard at 8 o’clock.”
(This is a pitch for the disgruntled TV audience who would turn the set off at 8
o’clock rather than watch a whodunit.) Similarly, we offer classical music night¬
ly from 0 p.m. to 11 p.m., across from wrestling, boxing, several poor dramatic
shows, etc.
We can follow the foregoing practice because we operate both the radio and the TV
station. Local conditions will dictate variations on this plan. We continue to
capitalize on good music. So far TV has failed to come up with anything that can
compete with classical music.
We try to offer GOOD radio drama. Recent RCA announcement that Old Vic is recording
pil 1 the Shakespeare tragedies on LP is good news for educational radio. Shakes¬
peare lends himself admirably to radio...his sets were limited...his lines told
the story. Shakespeare is 85% reading, 15% setting. We continue to promote radio
news. We feel radio can do a better job of it that TV...more completely...more
quickly... .TV news is limited to ’’All the news that fits our filmi" Radio has no
such limitations.
Educational radio, "Radio With a Purpose,” can compete with TV better than commer¬
cial "entertainment” radio. Puck (a comic weekly) recently announced results of
survey on impact of TV in major metropolitan market. Two pro-radio results: (l)
Radio listening in TV homes is higher among better-educated than among less educa¬
ted homes, and (2) After two years of TV, a Radior-TV home begins to come back sharp¬
ly to nighttime radio listening.
Note how network radio is meeting the TV challenge. More drama, more documentary,
more experimentation.. .the sort of thing NAEB has been doing for years.’ This means
greater competition for educational radio, but it also means more people will be¬
come awakened to the value of high-class programming.
As given at 1953 National Convention
Norman, Oklahoma
October 31, 1953
